script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, let's dive right into something that has always caught my attention in Genesis 5. It's this list of generations from Adam to Noah, mostly just names and ages, but then we hit verse 24: 'And Enoch walked with God: and he was not; for God took him.' What do you make of that mysterious line?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's such an intriguing moment, David. It stands out like a beacon in that genealogy, hinting at a much larger story. Thankfully, Moses 6 fills in the details, and what we discover there transforms everything we thought we knew about Enoch.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly. It creates this sense of curiosity—why him? Why that phrasing? Walk me through what Moses 6 reveals about Enoch's life.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 6:26-36, we see God calling Enoch to cry repentance amid a world gripped by Satan's dominion. But Enoch feels utterly inadequate. He says in verse 31, 'Why is it that I have found favor in thy sight, and am but a lad, and all the people hate me?'

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love how honest that is. He's young, stammering, and surrounded by opposition. How does the Lord respond to that vulnerability?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The Lord reassures him powerfully in verses 32-34. He says, 'As I live, even so will I come in the last days... Open thy mouth, and it shall be filled.' And then that youth theme verse, Moses 6:34: 'Walk with me.' God sees potential where Enoch sees weakness.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's profound. It reminds me of other prophets who felt the same. Like Moses saying he's slow of speech in Exodus 4:10.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. Jeremiah felt too young in Jeremiah 1:6, Nephi struggled with his weakness in writing in 2 Nephi 33:2, and Moroni worried about his weakness in Ether 12:23. There's this pattern across dispensations—God calls the hesitant and empowers them.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What strikes me is how this pattern builds across time. From Enoch in the beginning, to those Old Testament prophets, then Book of Mormon ones. It shows God's consistent way of working through human frailty.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and it culminates in modern revelation. Even apostles like Elder Ulisses Soares have shared feeling overwhelmed when called, yet strengthened by the Spirit. It's prophetic continuity—ancient foundations supporting today's leaders.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, that's a realization I hadn't connected before. So Enoch overcomes this, and Moses 6 shows his mighty works. But let's zoom out—what's the bigger picture in these chapters?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Moses 6 paints the family of Adam progressing through generations. Despite Satan's great dominion in verse 15, parents teach children the ways of God in verse 21. It's a story of light piercing darkness from the very start.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And then we get to Moses 6:48-68, where the gospel of Jesus Christ is taught right from Adam's time. That's transformative.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. Adam asks in verse 53, 'How to come unto thee?' The Lord's answer outlines faith in Jesus Christ, repentance, baptism by water, and receiving the Holy Ghost. Verse 59 even calls baptism being 'born again' into God's kingdom.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm intrigued by those symbols you mentioned earlier. Like hearts and ears in verse 27, eyes and clay in verse 35, water in verses 59-60. How do they deepen our view of redemption?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What I find remarkable is how sin blinds us—covering eyes, ears, hearts as in verse 27: 'Their ears were stopped, and their hearts were blinded.' God opens them through His power, like clay on eyes symbolizing healing sight.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That mirrors the Savior's miracles, doesn't it? Healing the blind man with clay in John 9. An ancient pattern fulfilled in Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It does. And water as rebirth in baptism ties directly to the plan of salvation—emerging clean, ready to receive the Holy Ghost as fire purifying the soul.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This really deepens my understanding. Now, culturally, what about that 'book of remembrance' idea? It sparks thoughts on ancient family records.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: In Moses 6, Adam's family keeps a book of remembrance, a practice reflected in ancient Near Eastern cultures where patriarchs recorded lineages and covenants. It ensured truths passed unbroken, much like our FamilySearch today.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Fascinating historical tie-in. It makes the gospel feel immediate—same principles, same need to record sacred things.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And the Lord commands in verses 51-63 to teach these truths freely to children: faith, repentance, baptism, Holy Ghost. It's the core doctrine from the beginning, as verse 7 says: 'in the beginning, and was not sent forth among men until it was spoken by my mouth.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: That resolves our opening mystery beautifully. Enoch walked with God because he embraced this gospel, overcoming weakness through divine power.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. His city Zion even walks with God collectively, taken up as in Genesis 5:24. A profound resolution.

script.speaker: David
script.text: One hidden connection that strikes me: Compare Enoch's empowerment in Moses 7:13 to Ether 12:27, where weakness becomes strength through Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Spot on. Another is Doctrine and Covenants 68:25-28, reinforcing parents teaching children faith and baptism. Ancient command mirrored in restoration.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And Mosiah 4:14-15 urges teaching children to walk uprightly. These cross-references show the unchanging gospel.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What many don't realize is how this integrates into the plan of salvation. From Adam's baptism onward, every dispensation points to Christ—faith leading to ordinances, spirit birth completing the process.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a connection that transforms reading these lists in Genesis 5. Not dry names, but covenant bearers advancing the plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. Each generation taught these truths, preparing for Noah, Abraham, and us.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Applying this today, when we feel like Enoch—overwhelmed by callings or opposition—God says 'Walk with me.'

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes. Like David A. Bednar teaches in 'Abide in Me, and I in You; Therefore Walk with Me,' it's an invitation to daily companionship with the Savior.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Parents, too—teach these principles as Adam did. Make your own book of remembrance.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And when weaknesses arise, remember the Lord's pattern: He qualifies whom He calls across all time.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, this has been eye-opening. Listeners, as you study Genesis 5 and Moses 6, look for God's voice calling you to walk with Him despite doubts.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Embrace the gospel taught from the beginning. Let it open your eyes, ears, and heart to His redemptive power.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. Until next time, keep walking with Him.
